reviewText: This movie was made in 1943, in the middle of World War II. While it is made in 1943, the movie places an American war correspondent (Robert Young) and his wife (Loraine Day) in London just near the end of 1941, and before the bombing of Pearl Harbor. During one of the bombing raids, Young's character helps rescue a small boy from the the rubble, the only surviving member of his family. Young is assigned to a human interest story at a nearby orphanage where he again meets up with the little boy AND another child survivor, a little girl played by child star Margaret O'Brien. Both of these children not only steal their scenes, but will also steal your heart. Young's wife is injured in a shelling of the city and returns to America. There are of course complications as you will learn...hey I don't want to be the spoiler here. In any case, a bond grows between the correspondent and the children, and decisions must be made. The film is based on a true story which makes it even more endearing. Oh, and watch for a cameo appearance by someone who will act as an omen of future events. It is not until the end of the film that you realize that what has been heartwarming entertainment becomes a vehicle of Allied propaganda. In all, this is a wonderful film; it says a great deal in just under an hour and a half. And the chemistry between Young and O'Brien is fun and amazing. Why not watch it for yourself.
Title: N/A

reviewText: JOURNEY FOR MARGARET, a moving 1942 wartime drama based on a true story, wasn't Margaret O'Brien's cinematic debut, but it's her performance in this film that made the world sit up and take notice. O'Brien is captivating and heartbreaking onscreen and demonstrates dramatic acting chops that belied her young age. I think she was only five at the time. MGM execs had earlier noticed O'Brien in a bit part in the Mickey Rooney/Judy Garland 1941 starrer, BABES ON BROADWAY, and were impressed enough that it was decided to feature her in a prominent role. And so a child star was born. If scene-stealing were an actual crime, Margaret O'Brien would be serving several lifetime sentences.If you have kids you should hug them every day. After watching JOURNEY FOR MARGARET you may not want to let them go. Sometime just after the fall of France, in a period in which English folk walked around with stringed boxes carrying oxygen masks, war correspondent John Davis (Robert Young) and his vibrant wife Nora (Laraine Day) arrive to London in the midst of an air raid. Despite the horrific conditions, John and Nora are trying to conceive. But a miscarriage leaves Nora shellshocked and she goes away. A burnt out John carries on and, while covering a story, is drawn to two traumatized orphans Peter (William Severn) and Margaret (O'Brien).Margaret O'Brien is so memorable here she threatens to overshadow the other actors. But I think William Severn as "Peter" submits just about as haunted a performance while receiving less screen time. Like O'Brien, Severn is neither amateurish nor cloying. Laraine Day is wonderful as the bright young wife who finds herself unable to cope with her miscarriage. Sherlock Holmes fans will no doubt recognize Nigel Bruce. Robert Young does a fantastic job of interacting with the children. He does this with sensitivity and, when called upon, with great humor.Most tellingly, this is about the horrors of war as seen thru the eyes of a child. What's more heartbreaking than a withdrawn little boy who chastises a rediscovered old toy - a worn wooly lamb - for running away and leaving him alone? Or a desolate little girl who lugs around a bomb casing wherever she went and who responds to anything an adult tells her with "Is that the truth?"? Anyway, hug your kids lots. That may be the most important thing you ever do.
summary: During the London blitz, Margaret O'Brien's breakout role

reviewText: I watched this movie years ago on Turner Classic Movies, bought it on vhs, and was thrilled to get it on DVD. The quality was great on my big screen TV, which says a lot for the restorers of this 68 year-old film.  The movie itself will move you to tears, especially the part where little Margaret lets down her guard for the first time after enduring six foster mothers (and the last foster mom you will want to shake!) I have a 1942 Life magazine article with pictures of the real Margaret, plus a first edition of the original book written by her adoptive father, and these make the movie even more special for me to watch. I would highly recommend this movie for avid history buffs like myself. I even recommend it for older children who are studying WWII in school. It gives a very accurate depiction of life in London during the Blitz, but it is not so graphic that it turns the stomach, as some WWII movies can.
summary: History Buffs, Get out the Kleenex!
